top_10_results.search_text: Parking Spots at the Brazilian Embassy The Department of State refers to the note dated July 29, 1965  from the Brazilian ftnbassy, and to the several telephone conversa­ tions with a member of the Embassy staff, in regard to the estab­ lishing of parking signs in front of the new address of the Brazilian  Military Mission at 4000 Brandywine Street, Northwest.  Since the Brazilian Military Mission is not an integral office  of the Embassy carried in the "Diplomatie List" of the Department  of State, a request for the establishment of reserved diplomatic  parking space may not be made by the Department under pertinent  regulations.  However, if the Eabassy desires that the signs formerly located  at the old address of the Mission on Leroy Place be placed at the  new location, it is possible that this can be done since the records  of the District of Columbia indicate that these signs were established  as early as 1955. The Embassy's attention is invited to the fact that  such signs, which, it is understood, read "So Parking • Brasilia*.  Military Mission" do not provide reserved parking space for any auto­ mobiles, even those belonging to the Mission.  -A S- Department ef Hate,  Washington. Septan 6, l96f I? 1 6 1365  9-15-65 Immunities. Privileges. The Department of State acknowledges a July 29, 1965 note from the Brazilian Embassy regarding parking signs for the Brazilian Military Mission at 4000 Brandywine Street. As the Mission isn‘t listed under “Diplomatic List,“ it can‘t request reserved parking. However, signs from the previous address may be relocated, but they do not provide reserved parking for Mission vehicles.

Goulartist View of the Present Political Scene (Conversation with Hugo de Faria) ORIGIN/ACTION  RM/ R  / REP  / AF  AR A EUR FE  N E A CU  3 INR  i  E p IO  /  L  3 FBO Al D  S//3  ) 10 1  AGR COM  3 FRB  INT LAB TAR  TR XMB AIR  6  ARMY  J CIA NAVY  OSD USI A NSA  H&  -4-4.  Drafted by: DEPARTMENT OF STATE  FOR RM USE ONLY  CONFIDENTIAL  TO : Department of State  INFO HANDLING INDICATOR  RECEIVED  DEPARTMENT OF STATE  : BELEM, BELO HORIZONTE, BRASMIM Ig)RTCHffffiBERE,  SALVADOR, RECIFE, SAO PAULO, MCOTEVlDEO  R S / ft N  ANALYSIS BRANCH  FROM Amembassy RIO DE JANEIRO DATE:  SUBJECT:A Goulartist View of the Present Politica  (Conversation with Hugo de Faria)  REF July 1, 1969  r  l_ Summary  Faria and his friends have no faith in the Government's,  present initiatives to resume the political process. They  do not believe a reopened Congress will have a real role to  play because the present Government, dominated by the  Executive branch under military control, will set strict  ground rules for its operation. He stressed that no  Government guarantees have been given to the opposition and  that Congress will be revived only to provide a facade to  tranquilize and confuse foreign public opinion. Dr. Faria  said that almost no dynamic MDB leadership survived recent  cassations and that the existing opposition in Congress  would prove tame. He does not expect a freely operating  political process to get underway in Brazil for five years'S  at the minimum. Faria believes the Government may carry  out agrarian and other reforms Goulart could never have  accomplished and thus the military might strengthen its  hold on political power. He predicted that the Church  would move to more moderation and caution in the coming  two to three years and that no important clash with the  Government will occur. He said Goulart recently instructed  his followers to avoid creation of any problems for the  Rockefeller Mission to Brazil and he authorized ex-PTB  contact with the Embassy to explain the views of his group.  Faria said exile has matured Goulart and commented that  Goulart, though with a heart condition, is reasonably well.  From other information, the Embassy feels that Faria's  views on present political developments are fairly t3  -<  •n  r—  o 1 T3  29 — 'v:  ' O  J  CONFIDENTIAL FOR DSPT- USE ONLY  {^fa •Out  CI POL:FJHaJhdler:cs 7/1/09 Contents and Classification Approved by  POL:RHShields A.  earances: GENERAL REPORTS & STATISTICS The document outlines a conversation with Hugo de Faria, expressing skepticism about Brazil‘s political future under military control. Faria doubts the effectiveness of Congress and sees it as a facade. He predicts no real political change for at least five years and believes the government might implement reforms previously unattainable. He also notes Goulart‘s cautious approach post-exile.

A spokesman for the Association told the reporting officer  that the Spaniards are bringing with them concrete proposals  for investment in Sao Paulo totalling several million U. S.  dollars, in joint ventures with Brazilians, and are ready to  discuss long-term Spanish export financing.  Manuel Fuentes IRUROZQUI, Mission chief and former Spanish  Commercial Attache in Rio, will discuss the possibility of  setting up a joint Spanish-Brazilian economic/commercial  research team to make feasibility studies to promote two- way trade. Sao Paulo manufacturers have already looked into  this, as a result of the recent visit to Sao Paulo of  Spanish Minister for Economic Planning (see A-85 of Sept. 7).  pX /?  Fuentes IRUROZQUI also plans to suggest the establishment in  Madrid or Barcelona of a Sao Paulo permanent business repre­ sentation using the facilities of one or other of the  Spanish Chambers of Commerce.  Sao Paulo also awaits the arrival of the Secretary General  of the Spanish Phalangist Party (Secretario General del  Movimiento), accompanied by a former Spanish Commercial  Attache in Rio. DEPOFF REQUESTED BRITISH EMBASSY TO ASCERTAIN BACKGROUND  •-40#FiB£NTIAL DEF 12-5 BRAZ 8-1-71 In April 1973, a U.S. diplomatic official expressed concern about a potential sale of UK nuclear submarines to Brazil, fearing repercussions for U.S. legislative and executive branches. Key worries included nuclear proliferation, the risk of sensitive U.S. technology transfer, and congressional sensitivity to advanced weaponry in Latin America. The official requested clarification from the British Embassy regarding the matter.

Brazil 200-Mile Territorial Sea Claim 3/27/1970 DEPARTMENT OF DEFENSE.  OFFICE OF GENERAL COUNSfC  WASHINGTON, D. C. 20W1  SUBJECT: Brazil 2CTfJ-Mile Territorial Sea Claim  The attached information summarizes our ship loan situation  vis-a-vis Brazil,  You will note that two destroyers and two submarines are loaned  pursuant to P. L. 90-224 which requires immediate termination  in the event of a seizure in international waters of a United States  fishing vessel.  In addition, it would appear that all other loans can be revoked  immediately either for violation of the "purposes for which  furnished" clause in our Mutual Defense Assistance Agreement  or in the case of the Navy-to-Navy leases, because the agree­ ment allows termination at any time.  Leigh Ratine r  Office of Assistant General Counsel  International Affairs  Att:  a/s Territorial Waters The document from the Department of Defense outlines the U.S. ship loan situation with Brazil, highlighting that two destroyers and two submarines are loaned under P.L. 90-224, which mandates termination if a U.S. fishing vessel is seized. Other loans can also be revoked for violations of agreements or can be terminated at any time under Navy leases.

Port-au-Prince 591, February 1968 INTER-AMERICAN A^AIRS  B. 11 FAM 500 MAR 6 - 1968  /  1. Galba Samuel SANTOS presented his credentials as  Brazilian Ambassador to Haiti on February 16 in a  ceremony which marked the end of a long period of  skirmishing between the Government of Brazil and  President DUVALIER over the question of political  asylees in the Brazilian Embassy.  2. In January 1967 the Haitian Government had  granted agrement to the appointment of George Alvarez  MACIEL (Port-au-Prince 931), then Counselor of the  Brazilian Embassy in London, who was to have come to  Port-au-Prince in April. The Brazilian Charge d1  Affaires at the time, Joao DE MEDICIS, several times  expressed the hope to Foreign Minister Rene CHALMERS  that the asylees then in the Brazilian Embassy would  be permitted to leave before the new ambassador  arrived. The Haitians continued to delay their  decision on the latter question, and Maciel's  appointment had been changed by the time the Brazilian  Embassy was cleared of all asylees in April 1967.  3. The following month new asylees took refuge in the  Embassy, and on June 8, the Brazilian Charge d1Affaires:  Alberto Rainho NEVES, was declared persona non grata  L_ Decontrol following March 3, 1969. " v  DCM: EKMelby V POLITICAL AFFAIRS & RELATIONS On March 3, 1968, the new Brazilian Ambassador, Galba Samuel Santos, presented his credentials in Haiti, ending tensions over political asylees in the Brazilian Embassy. The Haitian government had delayed decisions regarding asylees, leading to complications in ambassadorial appointments. In June 1967, the previous Charge d‘Affaires was declared persona non grata during ongoing disputes.

Parking Spots at the Brazilian Embassy The Department of State refers to the note dated July 29, 1965  from the Brazilian ftnbassy, and to the several telephone conversa­ tions with a member of the Embassy staff, in regard to the estab­ lishing of parking signs in front of the new address of the Brazilian  Military Mission at 4000 Brandywine Street, Northwest.  Since the Brazilian Military Mission is not an integral office  of the Embassy carried in the "Diplomatie List" of the Department  of State, a request for the establishment of reserved diplomatic  parking space may not be made by the Department under pertinent  regulations.  However, if the Eabassy desires that the signs formerly located  at the old address of the Mission on Leroy Place be placed at the  new location, it is possible that this can be done since the records  of the District of Columbia indicate that these signs were established  as early as 1955. The Embassy's attention is invited to the fact that  such signs, which, it is understood, read "So Parking • Brasilia*.  Military Mission" do not provide reserved parking space for any auto­ mobiles, even those belonging to the Mission.  -A S- Department ef Hate,  Washington. Septan 6, l96f I? 1 6 1365  9-15-65 Immunities. Privileges. The Department of State acknowledges a July 29, 1965 note from the Brazilian Embassy regarding parking signs for the Brazilian Military Mission at 4000 Brandywine Street. As the Mission isn‘t listed under “Diplomatic List,“ it can‘t request reserved parking. However, signs from the previous address may be relocated, but they do not provide reserved parking for Mission vehicles.

Visit to Maceio, Alagoas to Attend SUDENE Deliberative Council and Visit Local Industries UNCIi/iSSIFIED  MEt«)RAI©UM FOR FILE  SUBJECT: Visit to Macei6, Alagoas to Attend SUDEKE Deliberative  Council and Visit Local Industries, May 11, I966.  I visited Macei6 very briefly on May 11, leaving Recife at 6 a.m. to  arrive in Macei6 at 9:30 a.m. and returning the same day, to attend the  monthly SUDEKE Deliberative Council meeting. Attendance of the Council  meeting was only useful insofar as it gave me an opportunity to shake  a few hands. The meeting took place in the aioditorium of the Clube do  Trabalhador with an improvised sound system so poor that it was more  like watching a silent movie than a live stage show. A separate Airgram  will deal with the May SUDEKE meeting.  Most of ray time was spent with Jorge Arroxellas, the director of CODEAL  (Companhia de Desenvolvimento de Alagoas) who acts as the deputy to the  president, Afranio Lajes, a past senator for Alagoas under the UDN label.  According to Arroxellas, the principal recent industrial developaents  in Alagoas are the following:  1. Potentially most important are plans to exploit the vast rock  salt deposits which lie 90O meters below Maceio. On the basis of  Petrobras drillings starting in the late forties, this layer of p\ire rock  salt extends over several square kilometers. A Bahian businessman,  Andrea Sasi, has been seeking to associate himself with an international  company having capital and know-how to develop a chemical industry using  the Alagoan rock salt. So far, negotiations have been principally between  Sasi and a BelgianCompany (Elekeiroz?) and Dow Chemical. Sesi is working  on a preliminary study of a project which would envolve an investment of  Crlllp billion for a chemical ccanplex to paoduce caustic soda, vinyl  and chlorine and derivatives. The plant would be one of the largest  built in the Northeast and by far the most important in Alagoas. CODEAL  personnel as well as other Ala^ans I had a chance to talk to expressed  great optimism concerning the project.  2. Sugar mill equipment plant representing an estimated investment  of Crll. h billion. All ^ sugar usinas in Alagoas are reported to have  agreed to become stockholders of a company which, in its initial stage,  would be equipped to manufacture 70^' of the equipment required by sugar  factories. The company would be a joint venture of the Alagoas usinas  (joined by a few Pernambuco usinas bordering on Alagoas) and Five-Lille,  the French sugar mill equipment manufacturer. Five-LiHe is reportedly  reluctant to coramit itself irrevocably until the craapany has been organized  and capitalized by the Alagoas and Pernambuco usinas. The importance of  the plant would be that it would free local mills from dependence on Sao  Paulo manufactxu'ers who are reportedly a year late on deliveries.  UKCL/\SSIFIED E2 On May 11, 1966, a brief visit to Maceió, Alagoas was made to attend the SUDEKE Deliberative Council meeting. The meeting was poorly organized, serving mainly as a networking opportunity. Director Jorge Arroxellas highlighted two major industrial developments: exploiting rock salt deposits for a chemical complex, and establishing a sugar mill equipment plant through a joint venture to reduce reliance on São Paulo suppliers.

Rio Grande Licks Wounds As Fine Weather Returns  With the arrival of Spring in RGS, the moisture still present in the  air is no longer precipitating on such a systematic and widespread basis,  and the danger of further serious flooding seems to have been definitely- averted, in spite of the fact that October is traditionally a rainy month.  The Army's pontoon bridge over the Rio Pelotas has been restored, and a  similar bridge, located at no great distance from the first one, was nearing  completion, thus offering the possibility of resuming simultaneous two-way  traffic. Tempers tautened by excessive humidity are slowly returning to  their normal resiliency.  Although some persons have been able to return to their flood-damaged  ^homes, there are some 5,000 in Porto Alegre alone who are still sheltered ^  UNCLASSIFIED FOR  DS-323 T. LU  CO  OA err co  1  o  >- o Summary  With one month to go and five candidates running, the  Alagoan election campaign remains uncertain; ratification by  the State Assembly will probably be necessary. It seems  likely that Rui Palmeira will come out the winner, either by  ratification of a plurality or in a run-off against Muniz  Falcao. Hides & Skins: Trade Fair and Convention in Sao Paulo /ACTION  DEPARTMENT OF STATE  FOR RM USE ONLY  A-926 UNCLASSIFIED  INR HANDLING INDICATOR  TO  FROM  SUBJECT :  REF Department of State  BRANCH ^  Amembassy BUENOS AIRES DATE: March 12, 1964  HIDES & SKINS: Trade Fair and Convention in Sao Paulo  r ~i  NSA  3 Sao Paulo, Brazil, will be the seat of a trade exhibition of  Latin American hides from March 14 to 22, and the Third Convention of  the Latin American Association of the Tanning Industry (ALAIC) on  March 17 and 18.  ALAIC is an aasociation of some 1,700 tanning firms in Argentina,  Brazil, Chile, Uruguay, Paraguay, Peru, Ecuador, Columbia, Mexico,  and Venezuela, affiliated with the International Council of Tanners.  The association, which has been in existence about one year, is dedicated  to the promotion of the tanning trade and the exchange of technical  information concerning the industry in Latin America. Association  representatives in Argentina estimate that there are roughly 170 million  head of cattle in ALAIC countries, permitting an annual production  of 28 million hides. ALAIC affiliates produce approximately $US 300  million of tanned hides per year, of which Argentina represents 25$.  The current President of ALAIC is Francisco GRUNWALD of Argentina,  who is also Secretary of the Argentine Chamber of Tanners (Cgmara  Gremial de Curtidores). At the Sao Paulo Convention, the Presidency  will automatically rotate to a Brazilian and the Vice Presidency to  a Colombian for a year term, according to ALAIC1s present statutes.  The convention will inter alia consider Argentine proposals for  making the method of selecting ALAICs authorities an elective process  and establishing an annual budget of at least $US 5,900 with each nation's  share based on the value of its production. Subversive Activities in Londrina, Parana / DEPARTMENT OF STATE  FOR RM USE ONLY  /  Al D  /  m  <D  D, ra  ©  o  03  •P  CQ  •rl  M  c  O «H C O  fi 0) B  o o •a i4  CD K ,Q H Q  ^ 3 ca  CD  •H  P. o o A»96 SECRET  TO : Department of State Lcf^muT OF sum  euR^6 OF  INFO: Amembassy RIO DE JANEIRO  Amembassy BRASILIA  FROM : Amconsul CURITIBA DATEFebruary 20, fgijf,  SUBJECT Subversive Activities in Londrina, Parana"  COPYNO; REF E \  tion  E» Burton  L_1SERJE9«|B28P4  r The Consul and his family visited Londrina from February 15  to 17,the second most important city in Parana^, to participate in  the inauguration of the First Agricultural and Industrial Exhibit  of Parana!. Londrina is in northeast ParanS, an area predominantly  devoted to coffee, cotton and cattle.  While there ne met with several American missionaries resident  in the city and was suprised to learn of their preoccupation with  what plans there might be for their evacuation should the need arise.  They explained that the national political situation and current rumors  made them think of this eventuality. The Consul assured them that  their welfare was of concern to the U. S. government and that should  the situation ever arise for drastic action, they would be forewarned  through the U. S. grantee in the city as to what steps to take.  The only first hand information they had was that Autunes d*  Oliveira, a Baptist minister, was trying to influence Protestant  ministers to support agrarian reform, to be anti-capitalist and  anti«US. Rev. Autunes df Oliveira claims to be a friend of Juliao  and to have worked 25 years in Amazonas. He is considered by the  U. S. missionaries to be an opportunist and they claim that he  has recently become very active among the protestant ministers.  L_ J  SECRET  DS-323  Drafted by: FOR DEPT. USE ONLY  [^jln nOut  AFeldman Contents and Classification Approved by:  AFeldman  Clearances:  SECRET Infiltration. Subversion. Sabotage. On February 20, a report from the U.S. Consulate in Curitiba highlighted concerns about subversive activities in Londrina, Paraná. During a visit from February 15-17, the consul met with American missionaries worried about potential evacuation due to political instability. They specifically mentioned Rev. Autunes d’Oliveira, who was influencing Protestants to support agrarian reform against U.S. interests.

In Porto Alegre, the Minister made a number of offi­ cial visits to various industrial and commercial entities, and attended the  inauguration of Banco Crefisul's new headquarters building. One of the high­ lights of Morais' visit was a meeting in the city of Novo Hamburgo with the  leaders of the local leather industry. During this meeting Mr. Morais stated  that the government intends to increase exports to 2.6 billion dollars in  1970, of which kOO million will consist of manufactured goods. He also  urged the industrialists of the state to increase production and to loweis  operating costs in order to become more competitive in the international  market.  On April 27, during a luncheon offered for the Minister by the Federation  of Commercial Associations and the Commercial Association of Porto Alegre,  Dr. Fabio Araujo Santos, president of both associations, criticized the  federal government and indirectly Minister Morais for the continuing  excessive tax load which he claimed impedes the commercial and industrial  entrepreneurs in their efforts to expand. Dr. Araujo Santos further stated  that this high tax load which the federal government imposes on the commer­ cial and industrial sectors works at cross purposes with the government's  announced intention of stimulating and assisting in the development of the  state's economic infra-structure.  In reply, Minister Morais argued that the gaucho entrepreneurs have a  responsibility just as their counterparts in the rest of the country have  to share in the cost of progress and prosperity. He added that most of the  taxes that are presently levied on the sale of manufactured products are  ^jbhe minimum which the government can afford to charge. Response to Senator Proxmire Regarding Fear of Brazilian Invasion of Uruguay AUG £ o 1971  Honorable William Proxmlre  United States Senate  Washington, D. C, 20510  Dear Senator Proxmlre;  I am pleased to reply to your letter dated August 11, 1971  in which you express concern about fears in Uruguay of a  possible Brazilian military intervention and request  justification for continuation of our Military Assistance  Program and Foreign Credit Sales to those two countries.  As the newspaper stories enclosed with your letter indicate,  many Uruguayans appear to be concerned about the possibility  of a Brazilian military intervention. As a small and lightly -=^s^  populated country between its two large neighbors of Argentina \T\  and Brazil, Uruguay has always been very sensitive to reports v>>  which even hint at the possibility of foreign intervention,  (especially from those countries), even though Argentina  and Brazil have not intervened in Uruguay in this century.  The principle of "non-intervention" has long been the  cardinal tenet of Uruguayan foreign policy. Thus when  reports appear such as those in the clippings attached to  your letter, they understandably cause anxiety in Uruguay.  Whatever the attitude of the Government of Brazil may be  toward the outcome of the forthcoming Uruguayan election,  we are confident that the Brazilian Government would honor  the commitments to non-intervention contained in the Charter  of the Organization of American States, the Inter-American  Treaty of Reciprocal Assistance (Rio Treaty of 1947), and ^ ^  other Inter-American declarations. Furthermore, official ^  relations between Brazil and Uruguay appear to be quite  harmonious, as most recently exemplified by an agreement  this month in which Brazil granted Uruguay a 10 month  moratorium on Uruguay's $14.5 million debt to Brazil, as  well as a $7.5 million export credit.  Jo  i  7$> INTERNAL SECURITY. COUNTER-INSURGENCY. In response to Senator Proxmlre‘s August 11, 1971 letter, concerns about potential Brazilian military intervention in Uruguay were addressed. Despite Uruguay‘s anxiety over foreign intervention, Brazil is expected to honor non-intervention commitments. Additionally, relations between Brazil and Uruguay remain positive, highlighted by Brazil granting Uruguay a 10-month debt moratorium and an export credit of $7.5 million.

Department of State June 3, 1%9  DEPARTMENT OF STATE  POST DIFFERENTIAL QUESTIONNAIRE FORM APPROVED  BUDGET BUREAU NO. 47-R07S.7  INSTRUCTIONS  The Overseas Differentials and Allowances Act (Public Law 86-707) authorizes the payment of post differentials to United States  civilian employees of Government establishments in foreign areas. The information required in this form is for determining whether suf­ ficiently adverse living conditions exist at a place to warrant payment of a post differential and, if so, what rate of payment is appropri­ ate. Guidance on which posts are requited to report is contained in sections 072.11 and 072.12, Standardized Regulations (Government  Civilians, Foreign Areas).  Reporting officers should answer each applicable question objectively, giving detailed explanations where necessary. If the spaces  provided ate insufficient, use extra pages.  Many questions refer to situations and conditions which may not be the same in their effect on all employees at a post. Repotting  officers should describe these situations and conditions as they affect the majority of eligible civilian employees. (See section 031-3,  Standardized Regulations (Government Civilians, Foreign Areas)). Reporting officers should consult the judgment of a representative  cross-section of the staff, where appropriate, before completing the questionnaire. This may be done, for example, through discussions  with a committee composed of married men and women with and without children, single men and women, high and low salaried employees,  those who like and dislike the post.  If a post contains two distinct environments as, for example, an enclosed base or compound area in or near a native town, the re­ porting officer should phrase his replies so as to make it cleat to which environment he refers. Briefing Paper on the State of Amazonas Briefing Paper on the State of Amazonas /"^n V  Of all the states and territories of northern Brazil, Amazonas /  conforms most closely to the tourist's conception of the Amazon jungle.  Wide rivers, steaming rain forests, sleepy river towns with dugout  canoes and barges and isolated Indian tribes—all are present to some  extent. With the exception of its capital, Manaus, and a few minor  cities such as Itacoatiara and Parintins, the state remains what is has  been for centuries past-^?^nconquered and unexplored natural reserve  which may, or may not, possess potential for economic development.  While its politics, since the Revolution, have moved toward greater  enlightenment, honesty and governmental concern for social problems,  its economy has improved but little. Caboclas still collect^ rubber and  Brazil nuts, using the same methods of their fathers and grandfathers.  The majority of the businessmen, particularly in the inteyrior, still  view their role in terms of paternalism, a euphemism for keeping wages  and prices paid for harvested products as low as passible. Although  Amazonas is Brazil's largest state (about ^ar times the area of Texas),  its population, which lives wholly aling the Amazon and its tributaries,  is estimated at only 800,000, ^ardly more than a couple of large bairros  in Rio de Janeiro, This is in spite of a high birth rate, for it continues  to lose much of its educated y^uth to more advanced urban areas such as  Belem and southern Brazil, which offer greater opportunity.  The Economy  It is not innacurate to say that Amazonas still suffers from the  effects of the rubber boom era and its subsequent demise. Its economy  is largely based on the same extractive crops of "^O to ICX) years ago. POL13-1 PoliticalAffairs&RelLaborOrganizations The Amazonas state of Brazil embodies the classic Amazon jungle experience, with vast rivers, rainforests, and isolated tribes. Despite political advancements, its economy remains stagnant, relying on traditional methods for rubber and Brazil nut collection. With only 800,000 residents, most live along the rivers, and educated youth emigrate for better opportunities. Its economy still reflects the outdated rubber boom era.

The motion was carried by 88 votes against 60.  Thirteen Labor members, including three of the most influential  (Halvard LANGE, Finn MOE and Nils H0NSVALD), voted with the  majority, while three Center Party representatives and one Liberal  voted against giving the guarantee.  Whereas alleged adverse domestic implications of Borregaard's  planned move of its chemical pulp production to Brazil (i.a.,  reduced demand for domestic timber) loomed large in the Storting  debate last July, such considerations aroused little controversy  this time. Statements obtained by the Government from the pulp and  paper and forest industry indicate that there are few problems  involved in finding new buyers for Borregaard's current consumption  of domestic timber. (Borregaard buys a maximum of 200,000 cubic  meters of domestic timber. Norway's total imparts of timber from  abroad are currently 2-3 million cubic meters annually.) Borregaard's  move to Brazil may even prove directly beneficial for Norway in  that Borregaard will be able to offer a grade of short-fiber  chemical pulp which is not produced domestically and which is used  in ever increasing quantities by the paper industry.  The opposition against the state guarantee centered around  development aid aspects of the Borregaard Brazil project. One of the high­ lights of Morais' visit was a meeting in the city of Novo Hamburgo with the  leaders of the local leather industry. In reply, Minister Morais argued that the gaucho entrepreneurs have a  responsibility just as their counterparts in the rest of the country have  to share in the cost of progress and prosperity. Executive Branch. On February 19, 1969, Finance Minister Delfim Netto addressed the CIESP board installation, predicting a prosperous business year. Key points included expected agricultural growth, strong industrial activity, ongoing civil construction, competitive auto industry, reduced federal budget deficit, and low cost-of-living increase. Netto noted unprecedented conditions for achieving price stability without hindering business activity. The CIESP president expressed support from the Paulista business community.

Visit to Maceio, Alagoas to Attend SUDENE Deliberative Council and Visit Local Industries UNCIi/iSSIFIED  MEt«)RAI©UM FOR FILE  SUBJECT: Visit to Macei6, Alagoas to Attend SUDEKE Deliberative  Council and Visit Local Industries, May 11, I966.  I visited Macei6 very briefly on May 11, leaving Recife at 6 a.m. to  arrive in Macei6 at 9:30 a.m. and returning the same day, to attend the  monthly SUDEKE Deliberative Council meeting. Attendance of the Council  meeting was only useful insofar as it gave me an opportunity to shake  a few hands. The meeting took place in the aioditorium of the Clube do  Trabalhador with an improvised sound system so poor that it was more  like watching a silent movie than a live stage show. A separate Airgram  will deal with the May SUDEKE meeting.  Most of ray time was spent with Jorge Arroxellas, the director of CODEAL  (Companhia de Desenvolvimento de Alagoas) who acts as the deputy to the  president, Afranio Lajes, a past senator for Alagoas under the UDN label.  According to Arroxellas, the principal recent industrial developaents  in Alagoas are the following:  1. Potentially most important are plans to exploit the vast rock  salt deposits which lie 90O meters below Maceio. On the basis of  Petrobras drillings starting in the late forties, this layer of p\ire rock  salt extends over several square kilometers. A Bahian businessman,  Andrea Sasi, has been seeking to associate himself with an international  company having capital and know-how to develop a chemical industry using  the Alagoan rock salt. So far, negotiations have been principally between  Sasi and a BelgianCompany (Elekeiroz?) and Dow Chemical. Sesi is working  on a preliminary study of a project which would envolve an investment of  Crlllp billion for a chemical ccanplex to paoduce caustic soda, vinyl  and chlorine and derivatives. The plant would be one of the largest  built in the Northeast and by far the most important in Alagoas. CODEAL  personnel as well as other Ala^ans I had a chance to talk to expressed  great optimism concerning the project.  2. Sugar mill equipment plant representing an estimated investment  of Crll. h billion. All ^ sugar usinas in Alagoas are reported to have  agreed to become stockholders of a company which, in its initial stage,  would be equipped to manufacture 70^' of the equipment required by sugar  factories. The company would be a joint venture of the Alagoas usinas  (joined by a few Pernambuco usinas bordering on Alagoas) and Five-Lille,  the French sugar mill equipment manufacturer. Five-LiHe is reportedly  reluctant to coramit itself irrevocably until the craapany has been organized  and capitalized by the Alagoas and Pernambuco usinas. The importance of  the plant would be that it would free local mills from dependence on Sao  Paulo manufactxu'ers who are reportedly a year late on deliveries.  UKCL/\SSIFIED E2 On May 11, 1966, a brief visit to Maceió, Alagoas was made to attend the SUDEKE Deliberative Council meeting. The meeting was poorly organized, serving mainly as a networking opportunity. Director Jorge Arroxellas highlighted two major industrial developments: exploiting rock salt deposits for a chemical complex, and establishing a sugar mill equipment plant through a joint venture to reduce reliance on São Paulo suppliers.

Costa e Silva Denounces U.S. Failure to Assist in Modernization of Brazilian Army PELEGRAM Foreign Service of the  United States of America  OUTGOING Amembassy BRASILIA  Charge: Embassy SECRET  TO: DIA, ACSI  CINCSO Urm Classification  Unn PRIORITY  PRIORITY  INFO: COMUSMILGP RIO  OUSARMA RIO Unn Unn PRIORITY  PRIORITY Control: 9-005  Date: Sept. 10, 1965  1930  1. At Ambassador's direction I called on War Minister  Costa e Silva to ascertain his preliminary reactions to  idea of additional Brazilian troops for IAPP in DomRep.  ?  Substance of his reactions covered in State BRASTEI^19.  2. Costa e Silva expressed strong disappointment at  U.S. action on military equipment for Brazil. Said he could  understand delays and bureaucracy on military assistance but  could not understand U.S. foot dragging on equipment which  he wished to purchase such as radio sets of which he has  now contracted for 400 sets from French to be delivered  in sixty days. He was particularly vocal about M-4l tanks  which are not even in use in U.S. Army but which U.S. will  *  not sell him because of U.S. obsession that this type of thing  will start arms race in Latin America. U.S. insistence  on equating Brazil to other South American countries in  matter of military sales incomprehensible to him after  Brazil's entering two world wars on U.S. side, action in  providing political and military support In DomRep (which  was highly unpopular in Brazil) and Brazilian revolution  OIIiO.ki.-j . Coups. On April 3, 1964, a U.S. State Department telegram discussed Brazil‘s military coup, highlighting dissatisfaction with Goulart‘s failure to enact reforms and his reliance on demagoguery. The telegram emphasized the need for a new economic and social structure to avoid a crisis. It urged U.S. support for constitutional successor Mazzili to ensure democracy and prevent communist exploitation in Latin America.

POL 15 Church & IA-5 1968 (Classified) A telegram from the U.S. Embassy in Recife reports that the National Council of Brazilian Bishops (CNBB) has not yet reached a decision on a protest statement regarding IA-5. Two American priests indicated internal dissension within CNBB over the wording, with prior meetings failing to produce a consensus. The CNBB is expected to discuss recent events in Brazil during an upcoming meeting.

C. 20W1  SUBJECT: Brazil 2CTfJ-Mile Territorial Sea Claim  The attached information summarizes our ship loan situation  vis-a-vis Brazil,  You will note that two destroyers and two submarines are loaned  pursuant to P. L. 90-224 which requires immediate termination  in the event of a seizure in international waters of a United States  fishing vessel. Leigh Ratine r  Office of Assistant General Counsel  International Affairs  Att:  a/s Territorial Waters The document from the Department of Defense outlines the U.S. ship loan situation with Brazil, highlighting that two destroyers and two submarines are loaned under P.L. 90-224, which mandates termination if a U.S. fishing vessel is seized. Other loans can also be revoked for violations of agreements or can be terminated at any time under Navy leases.

Fr, Jorge Joly  Padres Redentoristas  Manaus  Dear Fr, Joly:  In reference to your two requests to the Alianca-Mirira Committee for  assistance in the Manaus area.  First off they have approved assisting with one well out in Codajas,  and a check for that wi^l be forthcoming as soon as arrangements can  be made to get it out, probably within the next two weeks. Enclosed  is a letter to Fr. Fish concerning the matter.  Secondly, the Committee has approved in principle helping with the  water project in Chapada, but only on a partial basis and only if the  inhabitants of the barrio raise the remainder of the money. Total  project is MCr^ 8,liOO,00 and the committee will supply the NCr$  3.150,00 when and if the remainder is raised. T},is money will be  set aside for a period of six months and if the remainder has not  been raised in that time the offer will be withdrawn. Perhaps a plea  to the (kjvernor might be in order. Also since the barrio is one of  working families, each family should be able to raise something to  help get the system established.  Sorry we haven't been able to do better by you on these; projects, and  hope that you canwork out something in the Chapada area. Please let  me hear Crora you about these requests.  With all best wishes.  Sincerily yours,  Louis P. Goels  Consul  ataiqao, aqii aguardaremos o deferiramto com confianqa e muito agradecidos .  Manais, 19 de julho de I968 ^'  Liberate Clementine Lima  Presidente, / AID AliancaMirimRefusals On August 6, 1968, Fr. Jorge Joly received approval from the Alianca-Mirira Committee for assistance in Manaus. They will provide funding for one well in Codajas and, conditionally, for a water project in Chapada if locals raise the remaining funds. The committee will reserve their contribution for six months. Fr. Joly is encouraged to seek support from the governor.

On the possibility of large-scale British investments  in Brazil, Mr* Gandy said that this would be difficult at the moment  because after two world wars Britain's resources are limited and she has  numerous commitments to former colonies. The following biographic sketch focuses on the  man and his performance in these fields.  Ernesto Geisel, the discreet general, efficient and dedicated administrator, the retiring intellectual chess player, is the son of an immigrant. He is the youngest of five children of a hardworking German Protestant school teacher who educated three of his four sons for the Army. All three became generals.  Geisel is a military officer who has spent a good part of  his career in non-traditional military billets, including a number  of years in administrative jobs, some ox them civilian.  The future President's first taste of the problems of  governing came after the 1930 Vargas revolution when as a  young lieutenant he was stationed in the Northeast. During  this period interventors appointed by the federal government in Rio replaced state governors and military officers were  frequently chosen for important political jobs. A-533, Dec. 6, 1966  r n  1. The Embassy's airgram under reference transmitted a  free translation of decree law No. 44, Nov. 18, 1966,  extending Brazil's territorial sea from three to six miles  and establishing an additional six-mile exclusive fisheries  jurisdiction.  2. It is the position of the United States that there is no  obligation on it under international law to recognize  unilateral claims to a territorial sea in excess of three  nautical miles and it is the policy of the United States in  the event of such a claim to formally put its position on  record and to reserve its rights and those of its nationals  in the claimed territorial sea beyond three miles. The  Embassy is instructed to send a note in these terms to the  Foreign Office.  3. The Department considers that the establishment of a  contiguous zone to a limit of twelve miles from the baseline  from which the territorial sea is measured in which customs,  fiscal, immigration and sanitary control is exercised, as  well as the exercise of exclusive fisheries jurisdiction in  such an area, are in accordance with international practice  and it raises no objection thereto.  4. Yingling  Clearances:  ARA-LA/BR S/FW^F WATERS.  BOUNDARIES. The document discusses Brazil‘s Decree Law establishing a six-mile territorial sea and a twelve-mile fisheries jurisdiction. The U.S. does not recognize claims exceeding three nautical miles and plans to formally express its position. The Department views the contiguous zone as consistent with international practice and raises no objections. Instructions are given for diplomatic communication with Brazil‘s Foreign Office.

At Ambassador's direction I called on War Minister  Costa e Silva to ascertain his preliminary reactions to  idea of additional Brazilian troops for IAPP in DomRep.  ?  Substance of his reactions covered in State BRASTEI^19.  2. Costa e Silva expressed strong disappointment at  U.S. action on military equipment for Brazil. Said he could  understand delays and bureaucracy on military assistance but  could not understand U.S. foot dragging on equipment which  he wished to purchase such as radio sets of which he has  now contracted for 400 sets from French to be delivered  in sixty days. He was particularly vocal about M-4l tanks  which are not even in use in U.S. Army but which U.S. will  *  not sell him because of U.S. obsession that this type of thing  will start arms race in Latin America. U.S. insistence  on equating Brazil to other South American countries in  matter of military sales incomprehensible to him after  Brazil's entering two world wars on U.S. side, action in  providing political and military support In DomRep (which  was highly unpopular in Brazil) and Brazilian revolution  OIIiO.ki.-j . Preparations for FY 1970 CAP ADPR Subject File  June 3, I960  Mrs. Virginia S. Murray  Office of Brazilian Affairs  Bureau for Latin America  Agency for International Development  Washington, D. C.  Dear Gini:  This will be a short letter today just to keep you advised of various  odds and ends.  As of the end of May, we were approximately 83 percent obligated which  is our best record for several years. However, we are still apparently  a few points below the regional average, dam It.  While we have not yet received the FY 1970 CAP Instructions, we have  begun to set certain wheels in motion here. Enclosed you will find a  memorandum which was sent to all divisions to encourage them to begin  preparation on the budget sheets. A set of the budget sheets are also  enclosed. Most divisions seem anxious to get this part of the exercise  out of the way. If we are successful in this respect, it may reduce  substantially the trauma usually associated with the preparation of the  CAP, assuming AH>/w does not have some surprises in the Instructions.  Also enclosed is a copy of a memorandum to the various divisions con­ cerning the preparation of the PASA PIC/T's for FY 1969. The newly  revised Manual Order 712.4 may cause seme slippage in fee target date  (July 31) for submission of fee PIO/T's. As you probably are aware,  this M.0. requires the obligation of PASA and participant funds by  Project Agreement. While we do not anticipate any significant prob­ lems in preparing these ProAg's, it is an additional burden upon us  during this season and will necessitate additional time for completing  this exercise. We will be advising Washington shortly about a couple  of specific problems we have with M.0. 712.4, such as how to handle  the USDA PASA projects and the obligation of Trust Fund items.  We were somewhat shocked by Beraie Gilbert's recent message which indi­ cated feat substantial deobligations in prior year funds for certain  PASA's, such as fee BPR, could be effected. We thought we had the PASA  UNCLASSIFIED PRM1-2 Assistance Plans 2 On June 3, 1960, Mrs. Virginia S. Murray from the Office of Brazilian Affairs reported an 83% obligation rate, below the regional average. Preparations for the FY 1970 CAP have begun despite pending instructions. Additionally, challenges regarding the revised Manual Order 712.4 may delay submissions. Concerns over potential deobligations in prior year funds were also expressed.

The text of the Statement is unclassified.  * * *  Having met for its first session, the newly elected Supreme  Soviet of the Seventh Convocation of the USSR reiterates,  on behalf of the 233 million Soviet people, its proclaimed  readiness to render the fraternal Vietnamese people all  possible support in the struggle against the aggression of  American imperialism. The Supreme Soviet notes with satis­ faction that the Government of the USSR, in accordance  with the Soviet people's will, renders to the DRV extensive  and many-sided help on such a scale and in such forms as  are agreed upon between the Governments of the USSR and the  DRV.  The criminal aggression of the United States of American in  Vietnam has entered a new stage. The U.S. Air Force is  ruthlessly bombing the peaceful population and the suburbs  of Hanoi and Haiphong, destroying dikes and dams in the DRV  and threatening thousands of civilian lives. January 18 Statement of FMP (Popular Mobilization Front) L-8& CONFIDENTIAL  Department of State  INFO : POLAD/CINCSO  AMB  mm  ]*OL(5)  POL/R  SVCATT  IHNECCN  ECON  FINATT  LABATT  BraeiliaI I ITB AmEmbassy RIO DE JANEIRO January 22, 1964  January 18 Statement of FMP (Popular Mobilization Front)  Popular Mobilization Front (FMP) leaders met in Leonel  Brizola's Rio apartment on January 18 and issued a statement  which seems to condition FMP support for President Ooulart on,  among other things, "immediate" action in the following fields  which, the document stated, are "ail within the exclusive  competence of the President": a) Institution of exchange and  coffee export monopolies; b) breaking off negotiations on the  AMFORP case, and the expropriation of public service concessions,  «-)including the Hanna concessions; e) expropriation of the  •^Oapuava refinery; f) measures against speculation by "foodstuff  monopolies" and the nationalization of foreign meat packers,  mills, powdered milk plants and pharmaceutical industry;  g) signing of the SUPRA land expropriation decree, which should  not include "small and medium properties"; h) a return to  their original units of sergeants transferred because of  "political persecution"; J) "democratization" of the press,  radio and television.  The statement also a) called for "effective respect for  the policy of self-determination and non-intervention, notably  in relation to Cuba, and support of the struggle of the  Panamanian people in defense of their territorial integrity";  b) reaffirmed the validity of the FMP statements of December  17-16 and "in particular" of Pernambuco Governor Arraes1  statement of December 18 (lunbtel 1270); and c) said that the  FMP will "intensify the mobilisation of the people by all  possible means".  GROUP 3: Downgrade at 12-yr intervals,  not automatically declassified.  CONFIDENTIAL  POL:AArbnales/rstp DCM - Minister Main  DECLASSIFIED  AuthorityjJ lO P S"3 I POL 13 Non-PartyBlocs FMP PopularMobilizationFront 1965 On January 18, 1964, leaders of the Popular Mobilization Front (FMP) met in Rio de Janeiro, issuing a statement outlining conditions for supporting President Goulart. Key demands included monopolies on exchange and coffee, expropriation of concessions, and media democratization. They also called for respect for self-determination policies and pledged to intensify public mobilization.

Collaboration of the US government in a study of air currents which may transport spores of Hemileia Vastatrix AGR h-2  ENGLISH VERSION U  APR fi Dr. Ezelino Arteghe  Secretary General  Ministry of Agriculture  Brasilia - D.F.  Mr. Secretary General,  I have received your letter of March 31, in which you express  the interest of the Ministry of Agriculture in receiving the  collaboration of the United States government in a study of air  currents which may transport spores of Hemileia y,aat,at.EiS from  Africa to Brazil.  I am pleased to inform you that we have requested the consult­ ant services of Prof. Frederick L. Wellmfln, a plant pathologist  of many years experience in the study of diseases of coffee, and who  visited all of the coffee-producing countries several years ago to  study Coffee Rust and to collect varieties resistant to the disease.  Prof. Wellman will be in Brazil shortly and, while he is here,  he will be available for consultation on this as well as other  aspects of the Coffee Rust problem.  Sincerely yours  Minister A. Ellis  Minister-Director AGR 4-2 Coffee Rust The letter from Minister A. Ellis to Secretary General Dr. Ezelino Arteghe acknowledges the Ministry of Agriculture‘s interest in U.S. collaboration on studying air currents that could carry coffee disease spores from Africa to Brazil. Prof. Frederick L. Wellman, an experienced plant pathologist, has been engaged for consultation during his upcoming visit to Brazil regarding the Coffee Rust issue.

UNCLASSIFIED  Classification  POST ACTION COPY E-1 General Policy, Plans, Pograms A telegram dated January 29, 1969, highlights a speech by Brazil‘s Finance Minister Delfim Netto in São Paulo, discussing major economic policies. He emphasized realism in acknowledging national resource limitations and presented goals for economic growth, inflation reduction, and reserve increases. The speech noted past successes and aimed to consolidate economic prosperity and strengthen Brazil‘s industrial base for 1969.

Initials  AM B /  PO  DCM  POL  EC ON EC ON  CONS  ADM ADM . u  AID  USIS  / •  V U *  FILE  Action Taken: Itamaratyfs Role in Formulation—of Brazilian  Foreign Policy  Brasilia A-55, September 5, 1970  Brasilia A-51, May 28, 1971 Q^Jlf*? fis^d&U^  On at least five foreign policy issues of currerlt  concern, Itamaraty is adopting a more militant position  than other ministries of the Government or leaders of  Brazilian society. In part, this reflects the ideological  commitment to an independent and nationalist foreign  policy by the Foreign Minister and other influential  figures in the Ministry and in part a desire by these men  to overcome their isolation from Brazilian society and  strengthen their position with those in power. The posi­ tions taken have struck a responsive note in the press and  Congress and improved the Foreign Minister,s public image.  They have also forced President Medici to exert a modera­ ting role reflecting the broader long term interests of  the country as he sees them.  1. Under its present leadership, the Brazilian  Foreign Office (Itamaraty) plays a special and somewhat  unusual role in the formulation of Brazil's foreign  policy. Its input into the policy formation process is  often aggressive and nationalist in viewpoint and narrow«  and partisan in character. Since the Ministry is led by^  a group of bright and experienced professionals and enjoys  a high reputation for technical competence within  Brazilian society, its influence in the formulation of  foreign policy is considerable. The document discusses the Brazilian Foreign Office (Itamaraty) under its current leadership, highlighting its more militant stance on foreign policy compared to other government ministries. The leadership‘s actions have prompted President Medici to adopt a more moderating role.
